channel.title: Comments on: Continuous Delivery – Adding the Load Testing Stage
channel.description: A Technical Community for IT Professionals

item.title: By: Eli Weinstock-Herman (tarwn)
item.dc:creator: Eli Weinstock-Herman (tarwn)
item.description: Unfortunately I was so burnt out just getting the plot to work that I never returned to try and do anything more advanced with it. More recently I actually have been working more with TeamCity instead of Jenkins (I re-implemented most of this multi-post project in TeamCity: <a href="/index.php/EnterpriseDev/application-lifecycle-management/custom-charts-in-teamcity">Custom Charts in TeamCity</a>). Given how painful I found the plot plugin to be in Jenkins and how long it's been since I worked with it, it's unlikely I'll ever return to try to get any additional use out of it beyond what I figured out so far, sorry.
item.content:encoded: Unfortunately I was so burnt out just getting the plot to work that I never returned to try and do anything more advanced with it. More recently I actually have been working more with TeamCity instead of Jenkins (I re-implemented most of this multi-post project in TeamCity: Custom Charts in TeamCity). Given how painful I found the plot plugin to be in Jenkins and how long it’s been since I worked with it, it’s unlikely I’ll ever return to try to get any additional use out of it beyond what I figured out so far, sorry.

item.title: By: Merlin
item.dc:creator: Merlin
item.content:encoded:
Great article!
Have you managed to get the URL generation (on-point-click) working for the Plot Plugin?
The doc says: “Optional. If set, this url is used when you click on a point. This is used as the base url for every point, %name% and %index% will be replaced in the url with the column name and index.”, however %name% and %index% are not replaced here with indices, I am not sure if I hvae missed some step…
Thanks!
